jparsec.ephem.planets

Class OrbitEphem

  • java.lang.Object
    • jparsec.ephem.planets.OrbitEphem

  • public class OrbitEphem
extends java.lang.Object
    Provides method for calculating ephemeris of planets, comets, and asteroids, using orbital elements, as well as for obtaining data of the orbital elements.

    Orbital elements for comets, asteroids, and other related objects (trans-Neptunian, Centaurs, Trojans, ...) can be read in two formats: the official format of the Minor Planet Center, or the format of the commercial program SkyMap.

    Orbital elements of planets were taken from the IMCCE's VSOP87 theory. They cover the time span 1000 B.C. to 5000 A.D., in intervals of 1 year for current epochs and 5 years in the remote past or future. Elements are refered to mean equinox and ecliptic of J2000 epoch. All planets except Earth are available.

    These orbital elements are suitable for accurate ephemeris, with errors well below the arcsecond level when comparing to the full VSOP87 theory. An additional advantage is the calculation speed.

    Example of use applying the main Ephem class:

     try
 {
                AstroDate astro = new AstroDate(1, AstroDate.JANUARY, 2001, 0, 0, 0);
                TimeElement time = new TimeElement(astro, SCALE.TERRESTRIAL_TIME);
                ObserverElement observer = new ObserverElement.parseCity(City.findCity("Madrid"));
                EphemerisElement eph = new EphemerisElement(TARGET.NOT_A_PLANET, EphemerisElement.COORDINATES_TYPE.APPARENT,
                                EphemerisElement.EQUINOX_OF_DATE, EphemerisElement.TOPOCENTRIC, EphemerisElement.REDUCTION_METHOD.WILLIAMS_1994,
                                EphemerisElement.FRAME.ICRF, EphemerisElement.ALGORITHM.ORBIT);
                eph.orbit = OrbitEphem.getOrbitalElementsOfMinorBody("Ceres");
                if (eph.orbit != null) {
                        String name = "Ceres";
                        EphemElement ephem = Ephem.getEphemeris(time, observer, eph, true);
                        ConsoleReport.basicReportToConsole(ephem, name);
                }
 } catch (JPARSECException ve)
 {
                ve.showException();
 }

    It is recommended to use the particular method for this class instead of the main Ephem class. The process is the same as in the Spacecraft class, changing Probe by Comet or Asteroid.

    Version:
    1.0
    Author:
    T. Alonso Albi - OAN (Spain)
    See Also:
    OrbitalElement, ReadFile, Ephem

      • getOrbitalElements

        public static OrbitalElement getOrbitalElements(Target.TARGET planet,
                                double JD)
                                         throws JPARSECException
        Gets the closest available orbital elements of a planet (except Earth) to certain julian day. Orbital elements come from VSOP87 Theory, and are available from Julian Day 1356173.5 to 3545468.3 (years 1000 B.C. to 5000 A.D.), in intervals of about 5 years except years 1700-2100, where the interval is 1 year. They are refered to dynamical equinox and ecliptic of J2000 epoch.

        These orbital elements are suitable for fast ephemeris calculations, with accuracy better than 1 arcsecond when compared to the full VSOP87 Theory.

        For Pluto an approximate set of elements (fit to DE102 ephemerides done by S. Moshier) will be returned. Accuracy of some minutes of arc between 1400 B.C. to 3000 A.D.

        Parameters:
        planet - ID constant of the planet.
        JD - Julian Day.
        Returns:
        The OrbitalElement object.
        Throws:
        JPARSECException - Thrown if the date is invalid.

      • getOrbitalElements

        public static OrbitalElement getOrbitalElements(Target.TARGET planet,
                                double jd,
                                EphemerisElement.ALGORITHM algorithm)
                                         throws JPARSECException
        Gets the osculating orbital elements of certain major body (any planet or Pluto), using certain algorithm. Considerations about time span validity and object disponibility in each algorithm should be taken into account before calling this method.

        The orbital element set is adequate for fast and accurate ephemeris calculations in dates around the calculation time (< few days), with initial errors in the milliarcsecond level comparing with the corresponding full theories, except with Moshier and VSOP algorithms. For orbital elements adequate for a longer time span use the method that returns the orbital elements from VSOP theory.

        Parameters:
        planet - ID constant of the planet.
        jd - Julian Day.
        algorithm - Algorithm to apply. Constants defined in EphemerisElement. Can be Moshier, VSOP87, Series96, or JPL DExxx.
        Returns:
        The OrbitalElement object.
        Throws:
        JPARSECException - Thrown if the method, date, or the object is invalid.

      • orbitEphemeris

        public static EphemElement orbitEphemeris(TimeElement time,
                          ObserverElement obs,
                          EphemerisElement eph)
                                   throws JPARSECException
        Calculate object position, providing full data. This method uses orbital elements. For planets, typical error is well below the arcsecond level between 1000 B.C. to 5000 A.D, comparing to VSOP87 solution or JPL DE200 Ephemeris. Results for dwarf planet Pluto should be accurate to within 5 arcminutes.

        To correct for aberration and transform to geocentric the Series96 theory is used for the position and velocity of the Earth in the 20th and 21st centuries, otherwise the full VSOP solution.

        For comets and asteroids, this method returns the angular size of the body by assuming an albedo of 0.5 and 0.25, respectively.

        Parameters:
        time - Time object containing the date.
        obs - Observer object containing the observer position.
        eph - Ephemeris object with the target and ephemeris properties.
        Returns:
        Ephem object containing ephemeris data. Rise, set, transit times and maximum elevation fields are not computed in this method, use Ephem class for that.
        Throws:
        JPARSECException - Thrown if the calculation fails.

      • obtainPosition

        public static double[] obtainPosition(TimeElement time,
                      ObserverElement obs,
                      EphemerisElement eph)
                               throws JPARSECException
        Obtain heliocentric mean rectangular coordinates of a planet.
        Parameters:
        time - Time object containing the date.
        obs - Observer object containing the observer position.
        eph - Ephemeris object with the target and ephemeris properties.
        Returns:
        Array with positions and velocities (x, y, z, vx, vy, vz).
        Throws:
        JPARSECException - If the date is invalid.

      • orbitPlane

        public static double[] orbitPlane(OrbitalElement orbit,
                  double JD)
        Obtain rectangular coordinates of the object in the orbit plane, according to the object's orbit: elliptic, parabolic, or hyperbolic.
        Parameters:
        orbit - OrbitalElement object.
        JD - Julian day of calculations.
        Returns:
        Array with x, y, vx, vy in the orbit plane.

      • elliptic

        public static double[] elliptic(OrbitalElement orbit,
                double JD)
        Calculate rectangular coordinates for an elliptic orbit.
        Parameters:
        orbit - OrbitalElement object. Eccentricity is supposed to be lower than unity.
        JD - Julian Day of calculations.
        Returns:
        Array with x, y, vx, vy values in the orbit plane at time JD, refered to the epoch of the orbital elements.

      • parabolic

        public static double[] parabolic(OrbitalElement orbit,
                 double JD)
        Calculate rectangular coordinates for a parabolic orbit. This method can be used for eccentricities between 0.98 and 1.1.
        Parameters:
        orbit - OrbitalElement object.
        JD - Julian Day of calculations.
        Returns:
        Array with x, y, vx, vy values in the orbit plane at time JD, refered to the epoch of the orbital elements.

      • hyperbolic

        public static double[] hyperbolic(OrbitalElement orbit,
                  double JD)
        Calculate rectangular coordinates for a hyperbolic orbit.
        Parameters:
        orbit - OrbitalElement object. Eccentricity is supposed to be greater than unity.
        JD - Julian Day of calculations.
        Returns:
        Array with x, y, vx, vy values in the orbit plane at time JD, refered to the epoch of the orbital elements.

        Transform coordinates from the orbit plane to the ecliptic plane.
        Parameters:

        Returns:

      • sun

        public static double[] sun(double JD)
        Deprecated. Better results can be achieved by VSOP theory.
        Geocentric rectangular coordinates of the Sun. Mean equinox and ecliptic of date. Not used actively in this library. Adequate for fast and low precission ephemeris. Ecliptic latitude is supossed to be 0.0.

        Expansion is from "Planetary Programs and Tables" by Pierre Bretagnon and Jean-Louis Simon, Willman-Bell, 1986.

        The expansion is valid from 4000 B.C. to 8000 A.D. Stated peak error of longitude is as follows (tested by Steve L. Moshier against JPL DE200): 

              years       degrees
 
        
 -4000 to -2000   .0009
 
        
 -2000 to 0       .0007
 
        
     0 to 1600    .0006
 
        
  1600 to 2800    .0006
 
        
  2800 to 8000    .0009
        Accuracy said by 1986 Astronomical Almanac is 0.1s R.A., 0.8" Dec.

        Parameters:
        JD - Julian Day of calculations in dynamical time.
        Returns:
        Array with x, y, z, vx, vy, vz values. z and vz are supposed to be 0.0.

      • getProbableDiameter

        public static double getProbableDiameter(double H,
                         double albedo)
        Obtain probable diameter of a dwarf object knowing the absolute magnitude and the albedo.

        The value is given by evaluating a function that was obtained after a fit from a tabulated table from the Minor Planet Center, called Conversion of Absolute Magnitude to Diameter. The fit found is excelent in the albedo interval of the table, 0.05 to 0.5.

        Typical icy objects in the outer Solar System will have an albedo of 0.5. Rocky objects lies between 0.25 and 0.05.

        Parameters:
        H - Absolute magnitude.
        albedo - Albedo of the object.
        Returns:
        Probable diameter in km.

      • getProbableAlbedo

        public static double getProbableAlbedo(double H,
                       double diameter)
        Obtain probable albedo of a dwarf object knowing the absolute magnitude and the radius.

        The value is given by evaluating a function that was obtained after a fit from a tabulated table from the Minor Planet Center, called Conversion of Absolute Magnitude to Diameter. The fit found is excelent in the albedo interval of the table, 0.05 to 0.5.

        Parameters:
        H - Absolute magnitude.
        diameter - Diameter of the object in km.
        Returns:
        Probable albedo.

      • obtainMeanMotion

        public static double obtainMeanMotion(Target.TARGET planet,
                      double a)
        Obtains the mean motion of an object in a elliptic orbit given it's semimajor axis. This method takes use of the mass of the body, so it slightly improves accuracy respect to default value for a massless object.
        Parameters:
        planet - Planet ID constant, can be any planet or Pluto, or any other to assume a massless body.
        a - Semimajor axis.
        Returns:
        The mean motion in radians per day.

      • obtainMeanMotion

        public static double obtainMeanMotion(double mass,
                      double a)
        Obtains the mean motion of an object in a elliptic orbit given it's semimajor axis and mass. The mass ob the body is considered, so it slightly improves accuracy respect to default value for a massless object.
        Parameters:
        mass - Mass of the body in kg.
        a - Semimajor axis.
        Returns:
        The mean motion in radians per day.

      • solveOrbit

        public static OrbitalElement solveOrbit(LocationElement[] loc,
                        TimeElement[] time,
                        ObserverElement[] obs,
                        EphemerisElement[] eph,
                        double maxElong,
                        double minDist,
                        double maxDist)
                                 throws JPARSECException
        Solves an orbit for a given number of observations, returning the approximate orbital elements of the body. This method is adequate for short time spands in the observations, so that perturbations are not very important. Observations must be sorted by date. Method is 'brute force' like.

        In practice, the recommended way to use this method is to call it setting, for instance, 0.1 as maximum allowed elongation. In case output is null, increase it to 0.15 and call it again, so the returned set of elements will corresponds to the lowest elongation of all possible solutions.

        This method is provisional until a better implementation is done.

        Parameters:
        loc - Object's apparent position (RA and DEC) in the two or more different observations.
        time - Time objects for the observations.
        obs - Observer positions in each observation.
        eph - Ephemeris objects for each observation.
        maxElong - Maximum elongation for the object. Setting to a high value like 1 will result in slower computations.
        minDist - Minimum distance to the object in AU.
        maxDist - Maximum distance to the object in AU. A better constrained range for distances will produce faster and more accurate results.
        Returns:
        Orbital element set, or null if no fit is found. The name of the body in the orbit object is set to the rms of the fit in radians, and the distance of the body on the first observing time is also given.
        Throws:
        JPARSECException - If something goes wrong.

      • obtainOrbitalElementsFromPositionAndVelocity

        public static OrbitalElement obtainOrbitalElementsFromPositionAndVelocity(double[] pos,
                                                          double[] v,
                                                          double jd,
                                                          double mass)
                                                                   throws JPARSECException
        Obtain a set of orbital elements knowing the position and velocity vectors in certain instant, according to the classical theory of the two body motion.

        For reference see Practical Ephemeris Calculations, by Oliver Montenbruck, chapter 3.

        Parameters:
        pos - Geometric heliocentric position vector in ecliptic coordinates, in AU.
        v - Heliocentric velocity vector in ecliptic coordinates, in AU / day.
        jd - Time of vectors as Julian day.
        mass - Mass of the orbiting body in kg. Can be set to zero if it is very low or unknown.
        Returns:
        A set of orbital elements describing the shape and orientation of the orbit, and ready for subsequent ephemeris calculations (all data except magnitude, mag slope, name, and applicable times). Mean equinox and ecliptic of date.
        Throws:
        JPARSECException - If the orbit is a straight line through the sun.

      • main

        public static void main(java.lang.String[] args)
        For unit testing only.
        Parameters:
        args - Not used.
